thig6.1:0.3: Paṭācārā, Who Had a Following of Five Hundred
thig6.1:1.1: “One whose path you do not know,
thig6.1:1.2: not whence they came nor where they went;
thig6.1:1.3: though they came from who knows where,
thig6.1:1.4: you mourn that being, crying, ‘Oh my son!’
thig6.1:2.1: But one whose path you do know,
thig6.1:2.2: whence they came or where they went;
thig6.1:2.3: that one you do not lament—
thig6.1:2.4: such is the nature of living creatures.
thig6.1:3.3: He must have come from somewhere,
thig6.1:3.4: and stayed who knows how many days.
thig6.1:3.5: He left from here by one road,
thig6.1:3.6: he will go from there by another.
thig6.1:4.1: Departing with the form of a human,
thig6.1:4.3: As he came, so he went:
thig6.1:5.1: “Oh! For you have plucked the arrow from me,
thig6.1:5.2: so hard to see, stuck in the heart.
thig6.1:5.3: You’ve swept away the grief for my son,
thig6.1:5.4: in which I once was mired.
thig6.1:6.3: I go for refuge to that sage, the Buddha,
thig6.1:6.4: to his teaching, and to the Sangha.”
thig6.1:7.1: That is how Paṭācārā, who had a following of five hundred, declared her enlightenment.
